description: Appearance: Aprajita is a small, spreading herb with slender, hairy stems that grow up to 60 cm in length. The plant often forms dense mats or ground covers in its natural habitat. Leaves: The leaves of the Aprajita plant are small, oblong or lanceolate in shape, and arranged alternately along the stems. They are typically about 2-5 cm long and have a smooth or slightly hairy texture. Flowers: The flowers of Aprajita are trumpet-shaped and range in color from blue to purple, with a yellow or white center. They are borne singly or in clusters at the tips of the stems and have a diameter of about 2-3 cm.
features: Appearance: Aprajita is a small, spreading herb with slender, hairy stems that grow up to 60 cm in length. The plant often forms dense mats or ground covers in its natural habitat.

Leaves: The leaves of the Aprajita plant are small, oblong or lanceolate in shape, and arranged alternately along the stems. They are typically about 2-5 cm long and have a smooth or slightly hairy texture.

Flowers: The flowers of Aprajita are trumpet-shaped and range in color from blue to purple, with a yellow or white center. They are borne singly or in clusters at the tips of the stems and have a diameter of about 2-3 cm.

Cultural and Medicinal Uses: Aprajita has a long history of use in traditional Ayurvedic medicine as a brain tonic and adaptogen. It is believed to have various medicinal properties, including enhancing memory, improving cognitive function, reducing stress and anxiety, and promoting overall mental well-being. Aprajita is also used in Ayurveda to treat insomnia, epilepsy, and other neurological disorders.

Active Constituents: The medicinal properties of Aprajita are attributed to its rich phytochemical profile, which includes alkaloids, flavonoids, glycosides, saponins, and tannins. These bioactive compounds are thought to exert antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective effects in the body.

image_alt: Rubber plant indoor live plant big size (Pack of 1)
category: Outdoor Living > Plants, Seeds & Bulbs > Indoor Plants > Cacti & Succulents
description: 1. Choose the Right Pot: Use a pot with drainage holes to prevent waterlogging. Select a pot that is slightly larger than the current root ball, as rubber plants like snug pots. 2. Potting Mix: Use a well-draining potting mix with components like peat, perlite, or pine bark. A mix of 1 part peat, 1 part pine bark, and 1 part perlite works well. 3. Planting: Place a layer of small stones or broken pottery at the bottom of the pot for better drainage. Position the rubber plant in the center of the pot and fill in around the root ball with potting mix. Press down lightly on the soil to remove air pockets. 4. Light: Rubber plants prefer bright, indirect light. Avoid direct sunlight, which can scorch the leaves. They can tolerate low light but may grow slower.

description: Roses require at least 6 hours of full sun a day (preferably in the morning). A well-drained and nutrient-rich soil, and moderate amounts of water. Water should only be applied directly to the root zone, not to the leaf surface.
features: Roses need a soil that drains well but holds moisture long enough for the roots to absorb it. 1 A loam soil is ideal?too much clay and the roots can become waterlogged, but a sandy soil will drain before the roots can get a good drink.

Use a high-nitrogen fertilizer or top dress with alfalfa meal (5-1-2) for the first application to jump-start leaf development, along with epsom salts to encourage new cane development and lusher growth. Add a slow-release fertilizer when shoots are 4 to 5 inches long.

Established roses ? water every 2-3 days. Newly planted or roses planted in pots ? water every day. As your rose starts blooming, take note if your flowers are wilting. This will happen in extreme heat but is a reliable sign that your roses need more water.

As a rough guide, in extremely hot weather you should assume rose plants will need watering daily. On a standard summer day with decent heat, you will need to water every two or three days, and in warm dry weather you will only need to water about once a week.

description: Rosemary (Salvia rosmarinus) is a fragrant and drought-tolerant perennial herb in the mint family that grows as a rounded, evergreen shrub with slender, needle-like, gray-green leaves on erect woody stems. Clusters of small, light blue to white flowers appear in spring and summer.
features: Rosemary likes full sun and does not tolerate any shade. This means it requires at least six hours of direct sunlight on most days. A south-facing window is ideal for indoor growth, and grow lights are often necessary to provide supplemental light.
Use sandy or loamy soil for rosemary. The plant is easy to grow when planted in well-draining soil and it can get root rot in overly wet or cold soil. A slightly acidic to neutral soil pH is ideal.

Rosemary is quite drought-tolerant once established, and itâ€™s better to water sparingly rather than overwater them. Allow the top few inches of soil to dry out between waterings, and then water so that the soil is evenly moist but not soggy.
